text: Clear copper brew with nice head and a herbal aroma. Taste is hops up front, citrus, spicy, then a hit of the caramel malts. Its OK but not great as I would have expected for the higher price tag. Well looking at the cost I would not only have expected better taste but also a higher ABV and for it to be in a proper bottle rather than a cheap CAN. So overall not good.

Pours hazy amber, medium white head and lot of lacing. Aroma of ripe fruits and light citrus. It gets lager malts, caramel, sharp bitterness balanced by ripe fruit and tangerine. Medium body, creamy, lively carbonation, long dry finish. Decent.

12oz can from Antioch Fine Wine, no can date. Copper amber pour with an off-white head. Some streaky lace. Aroma has fruits, light cereal and vague citrus and stone fruits. Taste follows and adds some sweet malts. Tangy in that old-beer Anchor Steam way. Medium bodied with some alcohol presence. The blend is ok, and the carbonation is constant. Finishes tangy bittersweet. Shrug? About what expected. 12
Can: Tang, wood underneath. Clear copper, medium yellow head. Tang again, artificial and sweet. Malty finish. Medium body, easy carbonation. Quite tasty, but I cant shake the chemical qualities.
Really nice copper colour freem cloudiness, decent sized head, no lacing. Tastes has some lemon, malt, caramel and bergamot tea. Has a really moreish dry oaty aftertaste.
Simple but effective almost a cream ale come amber vienna golden some fruitiness smooth on the palate.
355ml can. Pours dark orange with a medium head. Aroma is fruity and bready hops. Taste has fruity caramel malt. Some earthy hops.

12oz can from Sheffiel shop, James Clay importers bb06/2018 (hm). - Bref: the quintessential of judiciously dryhopped, drinkable ale-lager hybrid, UK-US and ESB-CaliCommon crossover. Aroma of Lady Grey granulate, tealeaf, bergamot and candied lemon. Fine caramel (De Strooper wafers) accomodating citrus and orange tea. Herbal and citrus pith bitter finish. Could be the quintessential oldschool US style even before IPA in its way of unifying mutually exclusive ESB-Märzen-Speciale belge.

Single 12floz can, no freshness date, paid the equivalent of $1.50, poured into a nonic glass. Color is copper with a slight haze, and the two finger subsides to leave lace. The aroma consists of cut grass. Mouthfeel is medium, and mild tasting of toast and black pepper. I can see this as being a lagered bitter, and for what it is, it is fine.

Refrigerated 12 oz. aluminum can poured into a glass. Clear copper, medium body, medium carbonation, and good small-bubble lacing. Aroma is floral herbal hops. Taste is herbal hops, caramel malt, and bitter finish.

355ml can. Clear copper with one finger slightly off white head. Aroma is grapefruit, light spicy herbal mint, caramel, citrus and gooseberries. Taste is grapefruit, citrus, gooseberries, light caramel and bread. Light to medium mouthfeel, light carbonation and slightly bitter citrus fruity aftertaste with a light sweet caramel backbone.

12/11/16. On tap at World of Beer, Hilton Head. Copper pour with a small khaki head. Light citrus aroma, pineapple, malty, caramel, biscuit. Good flavor, malty, caramel, toasty, biscuit, a touch of bitterness and citrus. Not bad.

Pours a coppery oranish color with off-white colored head. Citrus, caramel, cereal grains, and a light grass on the nose; follows onto the palate. Medium bodied. Finishes with plenty of malt, cereal grain, and some hay.

Can. Pours a clear light copper body with a large foamy white head that left some light lacing. The nose is lightly toasted and caramel malt with a little fruitiness and just a hint of leafy hops. The flavor is a bit more interesting than the regular Steam beer. The same toasted and slightly husky base, but with a little more of a hoppy snap on the back end. A lingering perfumy hoppiness. Lighter bodied with a soft fizzy carbonation level. Decent beer, a touch better than the original, but not by much.
Can from appellation wines dalry. Pours clear amber with long lived creamy head. Nose of musty cellar, shortbread, spiced orange. Taste is smooth, fruity, biscuity, underlying foosty bitterness.

A 12 fl oz can with no visible canned on or best by date. Poured into a stemmed Mikkeller tasting glass. It poured a clear copper orange colour with a just less than two finger off white head that had decent retention and left nice lacing. Aromas of citrus orange, citrus zest, grass, herbal, caramel and toasty biscuit. Tastes of grapefruit, orange, lemon, citrus zest, caramel, biscuit malt sweetness, herbal and floral. Light to medium bodied with moderate carbonation. Overall, nicely balanced and easy to drink.
Can from Crafty Bottle, Lincoln. Rich amber golden colour with a tan head. Aroma is mainly malty, and a touch of nuts.Taste mostly sweet, with a bitter hop finish. Medium body and very drinkable.

Can. Pale amber with a white head. Aroma of bread crust, lime leaf, grapes, grass. Medium bodied. Bread crusts and grapes, citrus and herbal notes at the moderately bitter finish. First steam beer Ive found genuinely tasty.
Can. Amber with one finger head. Seems like a sweeter, fuller bodied version of Anchor Steam. Caramel and mild hops. Simple, but very good.
The sweetness of this one got me...it is a nice pour and pleasant flavor overall and though a bit low ABV the sweetness really won me over. I will drink it again.

Sarasota, Fl - Total Wine - 12 oz can. Medium copper pour, light off-white head. Aroma presents some toffee and molasses. Flavor is decidedly sweet, with some ripening vegetables,  hint of molasses, some caramel. Thickish mouthfeel.

355 ml can from Utobeer Market Stall, London.
Dark amber, clear body, with a big, creamy, lacing, off-white head.
Aroma of sweet bread, flowers, sweet fruits, caramel, some grass, some herbs.
Taste follows this, with more citric and grape like fruit notes.
Medium, a bit creamy mouthfeel, with an average carbonation.
Finishes medium bitter, a bit dry, floral, citric, bready, lingering piney, with the grape notes dominating.

Very nice. Quaffable and well balanced, with the typical Nelson Sauvin grape notes shining through more and more towards the finish. Quite unique stuff, with the distinctive smoothness I love this brewery for.
Can. Slightly hazy golden color with small off-white head. Somewhat sweet malty aroma. Mostly sweet malty flavor with biscuit notes and a touch of hops in the finish. Medium bodied and drinkable.
Can from Liquor Barn. Pours copper with one finer of white head. Aroma is citra hops with a pleasant malt profile.

Poured into a becher pint glass, the appearance was a soft amber color with a nice fluffy white foamy head that held for a good half minute and then dissipated gently into the beer.
The aroma starts malty sweet bready/toffee flowing into fruity esters. Sweet all of the way through.
The flavor leans bready sweet the whole time. Quick bready sweet aftertaste running into the finish.
On the palate, this one sat about a light to medium on the body with a nice sessionable smooth crisp sweet feel rolling along my tongue. Feels super smooth all around.
Overall, really good Cali common. I dont see any dates anywhere but Im suspecting this might have a little bit of age to it given that its so smooth.
Dark gold color with a big creamy head. This has a bit of an Oktoberfest feel to it. A little hops at the end. Pretty solid.

Dark gold pour, quick off white head. Nose is yeast, little metal, and subtle citrus. Bitter. Middle shows caramel malt, bark, floral citrus. Finish is dry and lasts a bit. Similar to Anchors original, but definitely a different beer. Try it.
Can pours clear gold lots of foam. Grassy and woody -- what am I drinking, a clearing? Lightly bitter finish. Nice.
Pale copper pour with a dense white head... pleasant, but not strong fruity aromas... caramel malt body with light hops, bit of a metallic twang... very drinkable, but a bit uninspiring. Okay.

pours yellow with a white head. it has a savory nose rich with yeast almost cheesy. the flavor is sweet and savory. a pleasant sip. i will return to this beer at some point. although having read a previous review on the beer it doesnt make me want to punch some hookers like it did them, i do recommend it regardless of the impulse to punch hookers laking.
Can from Rehills, Newcastle. Hazy amber with a thin white head. It has a peppery hop and red fruity flavour with grassy notes followed by slight herbal, earthy and orange on the smooth finish. Nice.

tunneled out of prison, 12 ounce CaN .. . cool looking CaN .. crisp cereal and hay, smooth slick mouth .. medium carbonation, easy to put down, a good saturday morning beer .. . . time to punch some hookers!!
290716. Can at home. Pours slight hazy copper with a high head. Aroma caramel, toffee, and hops. Not the freshest probably. Nice steam body. Ok.

355 ml can.
Pours clear amber color with a large head. Aroma is hoppy and slightly smoky, some malt and wood. Flavor is malty and slightly bitter. Good. 
4424
can at home ... amber ... massive off white head ... soft zezty grassy fruit nose .. soft dry bitter herbal grassy fruit ... some citrus ... soft toffee

Can from Beer Gonzo shop, Earlsdon, Coventry, consumed at Truck Festival, Steventon, Oxon, Saturday 16th July 2016   Hoppier than I expected and a pleasant beer, fruity with a steady hoppy bitterness, frothy head, nose also shows a little fresh hop. Its a very nice beer. A6 A3 T7 P4 Ov14 3.4
Citrus and malt aroma. Clear copper body with an off white head. Bitter start with a malty finish. Earthy malt with a hint of citrus.

12oz can from Total Wine in Reno 
Pours clear dark golden with a medium sized white head, good lacing. Aroma of pale malts, citrus and pine. Flavor of sweet malts, caramel, grassy and herbal 
Good

355ml can. Clear, pale amber colour with average to huge, thick, firm, frothy, fairly lasting and lacing, off-white head. Floral hoppy, minimally herbal-soapy aroma, a doughy yeasty and a bready malty touch. Taste moderately bitter hoppy, slightly fruity with hints of red berries, minimally soapy, slightly leafy hop bitterness, cautious hints of bitter orange zest, spicy malty basis. Maybe the most paradigmatic (or quintessential) specimen of a California Common I had so far, exposing all the facets which account for the discreteness of the style.

355ml can bought at HK Brewcraft in Central.
Looks: Clear amber honey colour; One finger head with crumpety off-white foam which lasts for 3 minutes; Excellent sticky lacing with notable slight carbonation.

Aroma: Fragment full Ale malt, with very light passion fruits, light candied fruits, very light dark fruits, floral, honey, bread, yeast and light lemon.

Taste: Close to medium sweet Vienna-like malt, with light caramel, very light red fruits, light floral, molasses, dry biscuits, light yeast, light lemon, quite strong bitter hops and sharp grass. 

Body: Mid to full body. Slick and creamy palate.

Mouth Feel: Strong Vienna-like Amber maltyness in a rich and very smooth background with very distinct Bock-ish taste. Caramel and red fruit are light. Sweetness is moderate. Dry-ish with strong lemony hops to round. Good!

Hoppiness: Very light tropical fruits, light candied fruits, floral, honey and light lemon in nose. Light floral, light lemon and sharp grass in taste; Bitterness is quite strong for a lasting, mid-to-high astringent sweet-bitter finish.

After Taste: Very dry. Sweet, biscuity and bitter to mouth.
Comments: This one has good looks, rather underwhelming tropical fruit aroma, and pretty sweet taste. Yet the malty German Pils dryness and quite sharp bitterness kinda save the day with fairly balanced sweet bitterness. Drinkable, but I wish the dry-hopped aroma could be stronger. Okay.
12 oz can. Deep gold and clear with a large off-white head. Aroma is of citrus, caramel, light pine, some dank notes. Taste is of malt, caramel, pine, leaves, light citrus, and herbal notes.
Can. The look is clear, beige head, and copper in color. The smell is malty, caramel, hops, fruit, fir trees, and ok. The taste is hops, fruit, tar, sweet, caramel, pretty decent.
Poured from a can while sitting in front of my hotel room in Austin on a nice spring day. Hops but not overally hoppy.
Can from Bradleys. Clear amber with little lacing. Pine and resin hops with with subdued citrus. Smooth mouthfeel. Didnt notice the dry-hopping so much.

Drank w Matt after dinner w Kirk and Alexis. Translucent copper with small white head. Smells of strong grainy malt, quite fresh smelling, mild newly cut grass, lightly bready and floral (a bit like old/dead flowers, though not in a bad way). Tastes starts with sweet bready malt, then becomes quite bitter with some light lime. Body is medium, citric, watery but a bit slick and frothy in the finish. Nice, very malty esp in the nose.

Can from Brewcraft at home. Dark copper amber pour with foamy white head. Aroma is malty lager with some faint hoppiness. Taste is ever so slightly hoppier than I remember normal anchor steam to be. Well executed but not my style.
Can from Booths in Windermere. Amber with an off white head. Fruity hop aroma. The taste is pine hop with toasty malts. Pretty good.

Can. Lovely clear bronze appearance. Amazing fresh flavour. Dry and hoppy and very refreshing. This brewery was one of the first Americans breweries I tried quite a few years ago. They are still producing excellent beers like this one.
Can from Booths, Media City. Amber coloured with a thin head. Has a lager style nose, but a little more fruity-floral in taste with some activity in the palate.
Can from Euston Tap. Clear dark golden with an off-white head. Aroma is sweet, malty, caramel and bready. Flavor is medium sweet and moderate bitter. Dry and moderate bitter finish. 270316

[email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */, from Heinens, Cleveland, USA. Medium/light aroma with malts, biscuit and floral notes. Copper color with small, staying white head and clear liquid. Medium quite complex taste with sweeter malts, floral/fruity notes and biscuit in a slightly roasted fashion. Balanced with wide taste spectrum and short aftertaste with bitter malts. Medium/light palate with medium carbonation. Overall, rich, high quality product especially when considering the percentage.

O.K. ich habe die gebatikte Fanbrille auf der ollen Nase. ICH LIEBE DIE BROTHERHOOD und flog anno 2014 extra zum LOCKN Festival nach Virginia um mir einen Eindruck von ihren Livequalitäten zu machen. UND DANN DAS..............ca. 40 allerfeinste Craftbiere vom Hahn, extra gebraute Festivalsude und das BROTHERHOOD STEAM BEER VOM FASS ink. Sticker und T-Shirt. UNGLAUBLICH!!!!!! Aber wahr!!!!! Zu dem Zeitpunkt kannte ich den Nelson Sauvin Hopfen noch nicht, war mir aber vom ersten Schluck an sicher das ich gerade was ausgesprochen spezielles und gelungenes trinke. Mitterweile ist der Nelson Hopfen mein absoluter Favorit und mir bleibt dieser Bier als ein ganz besonderes in Erinnerung. Hoffentlich gibt es bald eine Neuanflage.

This is a oversweet and sticky APA-ish brew. Its clear copper in color w/ a big foamy head. It smells of woody pine and a touch of melon and citrus. Its sticky sweet, bitter and heavy on the palate. Apparently it was made by the dude from the Black Crowes but I am thinking possibly in the future they should leave the beer to the brewers. Except for the brewers in this case are Anchor and they suck so who fucking cares anyway?

12oz can pours with a clear copper body that supports a tall light tan head of foam. The aroma offers up lagery yeasty sort of apple esters as well as a mineral sensation flowing along with some floral hops that mingle with a dash of biscuit like malts. The taste is lagery where the experience starts off with modest smooth sweet malts that run quickly into lightly roasted malts and mineral notes. Behind that are the lagery yeasty esters and a pleasant modest spicy to somewhat floral hop bitterness. Pretty nice.

12 ounce can into lager glass, no can dating. Pours slightly hazy orange/amber color with a 1 finger fairly dense and fluffy off white head with great retention, that reduces to a nice cap that lingers. Nice spotty soapy lacing clings down the glass, with a good amount of streaming carbonation retaining the cap. Aromas of big grapefruit, tangerine, peach, pineapple, lemon/orange peel, pepper, pine, caramel, light toffee, toasted biscuit, herbal, and floral/grassy earthiness. Damn nice aromas with great balance and complexity of citrus/earthy hops, fruity yeast, and moderate dark/bready malt notes; with great strength. Taste of big grapefruit, tangerine, peach, pineapple, lemon/orange peel, pepper, pine, caramel, light toffee, toasted biscuit, herbal, and floral/grassy earthiness. Moderate amount of pine/spicy bitterness on the finish; with lingering notes of grapefruit, tangerine, peach, pineapple, lemon/orange peel, pepper, pine, caramel, light toffee, toasted biscuit, and herbal/floral/grassy earthiness on the finish for a good bit. Damn nice complexity, robustness, and balance of citrus/earthy hops, fruity yeast, and moderate dark/bready malt flavors; with a great malt/bitterness balance and zero cloying flavors after the finish. Light-moderate dryness from bitterness as well. Medium-high carbonation and medium body; with a very smooth, fairly crisp, and creamy/bready/sticky balanced mouthfeel that is nice. Alcohol is very well hidden with zero warming present after the finish. Overall this is an excellent hoppy California common style. All around great complexity, robustness, and balance of citrus/earthy hops, fruity yeast, and moderate dark/bready malt flavors; and very smooth, crisp, and easy to drink. A very enjoyable offering.
Very basic beer. Not really impressed by this. The original is much better. Light toasty aroma. Light hop zest. Lasting head. Okay mouthfeel. Meh.

Nice malty scent with light floral hops and caramel. Clear orange colored with a small beige head, good lacing. Crisp, mild sweet malt quickly giving way to a bitter follow. Not bad but not a stand out beer either. Id drink it again.
Can in Hawaii. Nearly a can gusher. Hazy amber color, massive cream colored head. Aroma of cereal and vanilla. Taste is caramel and cereal.

12 oz. can from shrubber85 through phaleslu. Pours a clear dark golden amber color with a medium sized off white head. The aroma and flavor have bready malts, sweet malts, grainy, herbal and floral notes, lighter bodied, just not much to get excited about.
A nice Californian common with a sharp nice hoppy kick. Goes down easy and is refreshing. Went down well with my pork pie.

Im not sure what to make of this beer. The aroma smelled like raspberries and cherries, so I thought maybe it was a fruit beer. Then I remembered this was a dry hopped beer, so that didnt make sense. The taste also had some of this fruit in it along with some dry piney bitterness. The body was a bit watery but it went with the taste. after reading the deScription, I think I might have gotten a bad can. I doesnt taste bad, just a bit muddled and not what it sounds like. Ill have to try to get another and re-rate.
Light haze. Light amber. Lots of hop, big no brewer hop and lots of earthy bitterness. Not bad. Maybe too much alcohol in finish.
12oz can from Hippo Beers. Orange with good head. Grain aroma. Caramel vanilla flavour. Seet resinous aftertaste. Good one.

Pours a super clear dark golden with no head to speak of and no lacing. Nose is of sweet cereals with so,e fruity angles. Not as hoppy as youd expect from a "dry-hopped beer" but this might be because this specific can is too old (no BB or packaging date... Ugh). Taste is moderately bitter and lightly sweet, english bitter-like. Slight honeyed cereals and peppery hops. Slight grassy notes. Body is medium, carbonation too and mouthfeel is a bit sticky. Not too hard to drink but it could be better... I need to read more on the california commons but this seemed like a moderately good example of the style.

Crisp, pure amber coloured body with a thick, five centimetre tall off-white head that stays afloat for a long time. Aroma of grain, light malt and pecans, some rough toffee and caramel and a light dose of herbal and perfumey hops on the finish - and a surprisingly complex smell - amazing for the style of course. Light-bodied; Strong grainy and malty flavoured with some caramel sweetness and a touch of fruit noticeable. Aftertaste shows a little of the caramel, some toffee, earth, light hops and the strongest by far is the nutty malt with not much of a complexity. Overall, a nice beer for the style, but that isnt saying too much. The smell was great, especially for the style, but the taste, less so. I sampled this twelve ounce can purchased from Whole Foods in Washington (Eye Street Northwest, Foggy Bottom), DC on 28-May-2015 for US$2,99 sampled at home in Washington on 03-November-2015.

Can from Tap & Bottle as I try to increase my CA Common count. Straight from the can. Pretty big flavor that starts with a hint of sweet malt and then jumps right into some serious hoppiness without huge bitterness. Very nice and bold for the style.

Bottle shared at Leightons. Many thanks to Colin for this one. Clear light golden orange coloured pour with a lasting white head. Aroma is dirty pine, orange rind, grainy, little stale. Flavour is semi sweet, nutty grains with light caramel, little grassy hop, Palate is semi sweet, moderate airy carbonation, Simple well made beer.

Can shared at Leightons, thanks to Theydon_Bois. Clear, dark orange, lightly sparkling, small foamy off-white head. Aroma is biscuity, citrus, quite light. Body is medium, tingly carbonation, foamy. Taste is thin malts, toffee, earthy with a papery finish. Alright, quite basic.

Can split at LKS high up place, from BM IIRC, 20/10/15.
Clear golden amber with an egg shell white covering. 
Nose is grain, bread, caramel, thinnish. 
Taste comprises toasted malt, light orange, sweet malt.
Medium bodied, fine carbonation, semi drying close. 
Not unpleasant just not a lot too it !
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text:
12 oz can. (The Liquor Collection) Honolulu, HI.
Clear deep golden color with a big foamy white head. 
Dryness, grainy malt, stone and mild hops in the aroma. 
The flavor toffee, dry hops, mild vanilla, mild coffee, mild bitterness and malt.

Can shared in London - thanks to Clon. Pours crystal clear gold with a thick creamy off-white head. Some piney and herbal hops in the nose, pale bread. Light sweet flavor with bitter orange peel, melon gummies, leaves, pine. Light bodied with average carbonation. Sweet finish, some earthy bitterness to finish, more rind. So so.

12fl oz can from Appellation Wines, cheers Ash! Pours clear copper with a thick white head. Aromas of light spice, resin, faint orange, light herbal note. Taste is heavier on the orange, light resin. Medium body, clean finish.

(12oz can) creamy head thats already fallen. Bright orange body. Nice hoppy aroma. Seems much happier than the standard Anchor Steam brew. Bitterness clearly lingering on the palate. Body might be a little on the light side.  ---Rated via Beer Buddy for Android

Can from Appellation Wines, Dalry Rd.
Appearance - golden with steady bubbles and a nice head. 
Nose - pine, but predominantly oranges.
Taste - more oranges, then dried orange peel, perhaps some raisins. And theres a lime tang on the end with some biscuit malt. 
Palate - light to medium bodied with a creamy texture and a long dry finish.
Overall - very enjoyable indeed.

Can. Pours clear amber, medium off-white head, dissipates fairly quickly leaving decent lacing. Aroma is citrus, pine, a bit dank. Flavor is light sweet, light bitter, some bready caramel, juicy citrus with a dank note. Medium body, soft carbonation. Interesting.
Amber pour. Big white head. Plenty of lacing. Slight malt aroma. Nothing else. Taste is bland malty sweetness. Drinkable. Just not flavorful.

Honey colored with a dense white head. Aroma is sweet and malty, with fruity hop notes. It's drier on the palate, and less flavorful than expected, with a lemony back of tongue taste, and a mild grainy astringency. $1.65/12oz

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Can. Curious Hop, Otley. Amber colour, with a light haze. Thin, lasting, white head. Sweet, fruity malts. Some stewed apple. Hint of hoppage. Taste is soft sweet. Some steeped hop bitterness. Soft fizz. Medium body. The bitterness rises on the finish.

Can from Oddbins Beer Shop, Blackheath. Copper coloured pour with a white head. Lots of toffee, caramel and pear drops in the aroma which segues nicely into the flavour with some nutty notes creeping through. Nice.

Can from Freshfields Market, Croydon. It pours hazy deep amber with a medium white head. The nose is clean, toasty grain, fresh bread and cereal. The taste is crisp, clean, bitter, bread, toasty grain, cereal, pepper, biscuit and hint of lemon peel with a dry finish. Medium body and average carbonation. Not a whole lot to it, but it is well-rounded and rather drinkable. Decent.
Pours copper with a medium head. Aroma is packed full of malty biscuits. A very malty beer with just the right bitterness at the end.

Can from Fresh Fields in Croydon. Pours amber and was a little lively. Bready and malty on the nose. Tastes of malt, caramel and bread and is a touch earthy. Its decent stuff but not an earth shatterer.

Can from Cornelius. Clear amber body with a thin off-white head. Lively carbonation. Faint lacing. Aroma of tea, musty biscuit and floral hops. Flavour of orange pith, caramel and lightly roasted malt. Thin to medium body with an oily texture. Soft fizz. Not as hoppy as I hoped it would be but a decent beer all the same.

First off, the label on this can was incredibly interesting and highly distinctive; it certainly gave me no idea that it was Anchor, which I take as a fairly traditional (though path-breaking) brewery. The beer was overtly hoppy but it had a restrained quality nonetheless. Finishes moderate, with a reasonably body and a light bitterness. Decent. Can.
Earthy, citrus, a bit bready malt, floral, super easy drinking, grassy, denser body. Really good for style and quite good regardless of style.
Aroma is floral, tropical fruit and slightly beery. The flavor is light tropical fruit, fruit/citrus, malts and a beery/bitter/slightly tart finish.
Can from Cotteridge Wines; clear burnished amber pour with a big frothy white head, aroma has toffee and bread dough, taste has sweet caramel, robust malts, a hint of spice, stewed fruits, ok.
12oz can. Cooper color with one finger head. Bready and slight hop aroma. Caramel, bready, and some pine taste. Pretty good and smooth.

12 oz. can; no date information present. Nice artwork on the can "by Alan Forbes". Poured into a lager glass. 

A - Looks nice. It pours with an amber-orange body thats clear with a large amount of visible carbonation. A generous size, creamy, bone-colored head sits on top and proves to be durable. 

Aroma - More hoppy than malty, with hints of citrus fruits, biscuits, and a touch of floral elements. 

Flavor - Clean, with more dominant bready malts, but with hops adding some nice fruity and spicy notes. Excellent complexity for a fairly mild lager. 

Mouthfeel - A very smooth mouthfeel, albeit crisp and with medium-high carbonation. Medium body; dry finish.

Overall: another fine steam beer from Anchor; Id like to try this side-by side with Anchor Steam some day. I havent had the latter in a while but I think this is more flavorful.
Can from Beer Gonzo, Coventry. Aromas of vanilla, some citrus and herb. Taste is smooth slightly piney, creamy, slight bitterness and a neutral finish. Some fizziness on the tongue.

Bottle from We Brought Beer in Balham. Steam Beer is my favorite nostalgic go to craft beer. One of the first I drank and since then its always been a regular for me. Always interesting to get this new hopped versions of classics. Saison Dupont and Duvel have done it very well and Im pleased to say Anchor have really nailed it. It drank a regular steam beer to compare the different. Colour is the same clear caramel light brown beer with an off white foam head. Nose is the usual earthy hop, Autumn leaves, pine, caramel, but the spices have gone up a few notches and theres a bit of sherbert and sweetness coming through too. On the taste you get the dry hops and its really really nice. Caramel is still there giving the beer backbone, but the Autumn leaf, earthiness, spice, pine, and that sherbertiness is there. Its basically Steam Beer dialed up to 11 and I really like it. Hasnt lost any balance at all, and has a nice spicy, earthy, herbal, sherberty dry hop kick which for me shades it over the regular version. I think the body is also a bit more full than the regular. Hope they keep making this! Will have to stock a few more. On the finish theres some really nice lingering earthy, dry, pine, Autumn leaves and sherbert.

(En fût au Lucky Balwins): Une bonne minéralité combiné à un profil houblonné terreux mais fruité. Les céréales grillées légèrement remontent à la surface rapidement avec une panoplie desters fruités.

12 oz can. Pours a rather nice dark copper. Lively white head, much retention, nice lacing. Aroma is malt, some warm spices, lightly hopped. Flavor is bready malt, then turns moderately hoppy to finish. Slightly bitter. Body is more like a lager. Very light. Pretty much what youd expect a Steam-hopped beer to be: easily drinkable, and not very memorable. If I lived in San Francisco (or wherever this stuff flows like water), and I had few choices, Id happily drink this regularly and not think about it once.

PS. The artwork on the can is amazing.

Anchor Brewing out of San Francisco was one of Americas first true craft breweries (well before that term was coined). Theyre best known for their trademarked Anchor Steam beer  which is an interesting lager/ale hybrid. Ive always found it to be okay, but nothing special. This edition, the Brotherhood Steam Beer is a modernizing of the recipe with plenty of hop aroma, flavor and bitterness. Is it any wonder I like it better than the original?

I poured a 12oz can into a mug. There was no freshness date. It cost $3.25 ($0.29 per ounce).

Appearance: Beautiful copper color; quite clear with tiny, slow carbonation bubbles visible. Pours to an average-sized, white, soapy head which retains laces pretty well.

Smell: Lovely hop aroma with notes of pine, grass and perhaps a touch of mint or some herbal character.

Taste: While I wouldnt say this beer is absolutely wonderfully delicious, I will say that it is well-balanced with plenty of hop and malt character that create for an interesting dynamic, but also complement each other. Similar to a Vienna lager, theres a nice taste of the amber malts here; they create for a lightly sweet caramel and bready flavor. Lingering in the background is a mild zesty taste of grassy hops and a firm bitterness. On the back end the hops become much more prominent and even bite a little. Pine needles and a light kiss of mint are noticeable. It might not sound like a good combination, but they actually play off the malt base nicely. This is much more interesting than Anchors flagship steam beer  I hope they make this a perennial offering and not just a one-off.

Drinkability: The thing about steam beers (a.k.a. California Commons) is that they tend to have the taste of ale but the body of a lager. Brotherhood Steam Beer is a bit bigger in body than the average lager, but maintains the consistent carbonation and accompanying crispness of a lager. The hops actually linger for a bit and leave a slight starchy sensation. I would not call this beer refreshing, but it easy very easy to drink quickly. At 5.6% ABV this is strong enough to stand up to a meal, but still light enough to tempt you into sessioning it.

RATING: 8/10

Poured from a 12 OZ can into a pint glass. 
Aroma- The aroma is mostly hops and some biscuit.
Appearance- A nice copper color with a medium sized white head.
Taste- The flavor is a really good blend of malt and hops. 
Palate- A medium bodied brew with moderate carbonation
Overall- Another winner from Anchor Steam

Une bière cuivrée avec une maudite belle mousse tenace qui génère une belle dentelle. Le nez de petits fruits rouges et de malts toastés est tout à fait agréable. Le goût de grains et dherbes est moins intéressant. Pas mauvais mais loin dêtre très bon. La bouche est bien structurée avec ses bulles vives et son corps léger. La finale est sèche sur des notes herbacées. Une canette de 355 ml bue à la campagne.
12oz can. Poured a golden color with an averaged sized head. Earthy, some citrus, grains and malty.

12 oz. can from Dutchs. Pours a bright, clear copper color with a small off-white head that settles into a ring and leaves spots in the glass. Notes of grass, grains, leaves, sweet malts, and florals. Light-bodied, with moderate to medium carbonation and a bitter, leafy, lightly malty mouthfeel. A bit uneven. Sounds more interesting than the original based on the description, but its not really any better.
I believe the first California Common I tried, refers a lot to the British Pale Ale or Bitters but with American hops.

Can sample at Beer and Beyond shop. Cool label design. Clear orange with a white head. Smell of stale fruity hops, caramel, honey, candy. Sweet malty flavors with notes of fruits, grainy malt, caramel, dry finish. Light-bodied, crispy mouthfeel. Probably better when fresh.

Can from my Yankee neighbour Rachel -- thanks! Pretty sure this is my first beer of this style & pretty cool to see how highly rated it is. Pours the colour of my kitchen table with a thin layer of foam on top. The nose picks up the grassy dry hops & could put you in mind of a decent English style IPA. A very clean flavour, with a crisp, dry finish & interesting bitterness. Really refreshing & am really happy to have been able to try it.

Can sample at Beer and Beyond, Tel Aviv. Clear golden with small off-white head. Sweetish fruity aroma, hoppy and quite malty. Sweet flavor with notes of honey and citrus, light hoppy bitterness, lager-ish and dry. Medium-bodied.

Honey orange color. Looks frosty, probably because of how the can keeps it cold. Looks really good.

Aroma is chlorine, English sugars, sweet crystal(?) malts. The hops that do exist are of the bittering variety only. Pleasant, but very basic.

The flavor is molasses and heavy sugar. Again, supremely English. Pleasant enough. Touch of apple juice in the aftertaste. A supreme Euro bitterness.

The palate is slick, medium bodied, not too thick. This is a very specific style of an English ale. Its fine, its just not my cuppa.

12 oz. can. Pours a copper color with thick white head. Aroma of medium hops, anchor yeast. Some bread notres. Flavor is herbal bitterness, yeast and malt sweetness. Somewhat bready. Full bodied with above average carbonation. Overall, interesting.

Can. Poured clear copper color with an average off-white frothy head that mostly lasted with very good lacing. Moderate hop and earthy malt aroma. Medium body with a slick texture and soft carbonation. Medium balanced flavor with a medium bittersweet finish of moderate duration. Good drinkable brew.

Anchor Brotherhood Steam Beer has a profoundly thick, foamy, cream-colored head, heavy lacing left behind on the glass, and a fairly clear, bubbly, amber appearance. Aroma is of caramel, some citrus, and bread crust. Taste is of those elements, along with a quite bitter hop finish. Mouthfeel is medium and slick, and Anchor Brotherhood Steam Beer finishes on the dry side and moderately drinkable. RJT

Poured from can. Aroma of dry hops and ocean. Good lookin solid copper with lacing. I taste piney and grassy hops along with caramel malt. Not as hopped as an IPA, and it shouldnt be. Maybe some yeast and spice notes. Crisp feel. Thats about it. Delicious.
user_location: York, SC via NJ, South Carolina, USA

text: Amber color with a small, off white head that left nice lacing on the glass. Aroma of caramel malts, some toffee, grassy hops. Taste of caramel, nuts, wood, grassy bitterness in the finish.
(tap) clear, bright amber colour with a small beige head; aroma of sour fruit; balanced flavour with a long, light bitter finish
Can, BBOTMC. Pours golden with a nice head, aroma of malt, wheat, cream, sugars, vanilla, flavor is bitter with malt, toasted bread, toffee, medium bodied.

Can, bbotmc. clear-to-hazy copper with a white head. Mainly caramel and biscuit notes with some flowers. Tastes mostly of biscuit, followed by bitterness derived from hops, though a little old. Medium body, quite carbonated, mellow bitter finish. Old.

How: Can. Shared by JulienHuxley, thanks! Split 2-ways. 

>>> My experience with Steam beers is limited, but this is a quenching leafy hops forward beer with a decent toasted malt backbone that I wouldnt mind drinking on a regular basis.

+  This is really easy drinking and quenching 
+  Theres a nice leafy/herbal hops profile, leaving an interesting bitterness 
+  Interesting toasted cereals profile 
−  Mouthfeel is borderline watery 
○  This is way superior to the regular Anchor Steam Beer 

Flavors:  Leafy/herbal hops, peppery notes, cereals
Can. Toffee malt and grass aroma. Dark golden yellow with large off-white head. Sweet light citrus toffee malt and moderately bitter herbal grass flavor. Medium body.
a litlle thicker in the body with some wood. some hops the beer is smooth and still sudsy, really creamy. a pepper like in the finish.
Can from Tasty Beverage, Asheville. Clear orange, nice big head. Clear orange, nice big head. Smells like caramel and grassy hops. Tastes like stale bread and caramel, then a clean, grassy hop bite.

Can, shared with Tom. Clear amber pour with thin creamy white head. Aroma is malty, peppery hop notes, mild toasty notes. Taste is quite hoppy, nice leafy peppery hop, nice bitterness, especially for the style, a bit watery perhaps. Palate is light, med carbonation. Good.

Clear copper color with a big orange-tinged white head. Aroma piney and sweet, not very pungent. Taste of bitter orange, possibly orange rind. Unpleasant aftertaste or orange rind on palate. Not very good. (Possibly this was an old can? No best by date that I could find...)
Brewed in "collaboration" with the Chris Robinson Brotherhood, the band of Black Crowes frontman Chris Robinson. Beer needs more Rock Stars.

12 ounce can thanks to drsilverworm. The beer is a clear copper color with a white head of foam. Good retention. The aroma has doughy, biscuit malts, crisp, grassy hops. Mildly bitter throughout, and leaves a doughy taste in the finish. Crisp and easy drinking. Medium carbonation.

Can shared at a tasting at Stass place. Better Beer Of The Month Club. Clear copper with an off-white head. Aroma of malt, a bit of cardboard, a bit of honey, stale hops. Sweetish malty flavor, with a bit of caramel, a honey note, and a bitter hoppy finish. Medium-bodied.

Can:
Slightly hazy amber with a thick beige head.
Caramel, sweet grain aroma.
Taste is creamy....caramel malt, grains, a bit of bitter leaf and nut.
Nice, mild, earthy bitter hopping....malty....
Very enjoyable.

ドライホップ  
ホッピーでは&

Draft. Clear copper pour with a small white head and good lacing. Malty caramel aroma with a small citrus and earthy hop note. Great balanced flavor, to style despite the uncommon ingredients. Malty base, rather dry. Medium bodied and easy to drink. Great steam beer!

On tap at the Beer House Chicago in Lombard, IL. as a 5 oz. serving dispensed to a flight glass, showing a clear, orangey gold color, with a frothy layer of cream-toned head foam, and clingy ribbons of lacing. The nose was slightly dank, with some soft grain, light caramel, and pit fruit hints as peach/apricot. Medium bodied, with decent carbonation, the taste continued the light fruitiness, and added a moderate bitterness that was earthy, and lightly rind-like. Heftier than the original.

Sampled from the tap at the St. Paul Summer Beer Fest. Pours a clear orangish gold with an off-white head that lasts throughout the beer. Aroma has a bit of musty grass, a hint of pine and an earthy grain backing. Flavor has a little bit more crisp grass with a hint of pine and some mealy grain/biscuit for the backbone.
Nice looking beer. Clear copper and a good head. The aroma is a caramel malt, a bit of raisins, and a bit of the Sauvin hop aromatics. Slight tartness in the flavor. Not a bad beer at all.
nothing special, but balanced and enjoyable. light caramel and floral/fruity hops. easy drinking start to finish. Id get again.
Rich copper color very light head. Hoppy aroma of a typical ale. Rich full hop flavor balanced well with malt caramel flavor.

Can, bright amber, big white head. Aroma is yeast and fermenting vegetation, some malt. Taste is nutty, malty, faint light fruit and spruce, faintly bitter finish. If this has hops in it I cant tell. Doesnt help that this follows a decent IPA in my glass, but when they say dry hopped, I expect more. Palate is decent, carbonation soft and moderate.

Light amber with a big white head. Aroma is light hops with very mild pine. Flavor is crisp, hoppy with something a little grassy in the finish. 

Wife: 3.9
caramel and grapefruit aromas, pours a hazy amber color. distinct smell of caramel and hopps. easy to drink but pretty malty for my liking. slight citrus flavor. average beer.

Pour is a clear amber with a average white head. Aroma is a decent caramel malt with a minor whiff of some citrus hops. Flavor is pretty much the same as the aroma. Semi-sweet caramel malt to start then finishes with some of the dry hops. Neither good nor bad, its just a beer to drink while not thinking to much about it.
Can. Copper beer with a dark cream head. Caramel and grapefruit aroma. Mineral and caramel flavor with citrus. Medium bodied. Mineral and caramel lingers with biscuit malt and light citrus.

Bottle. Semi hazy orange amber beer with a large white head. Aroma is fruity with notes of citrus, lime, caiperina, sugar and peaches. Flavor is fruity with notes of caramel, citrus, peaches, oranges and yeast. Well balanced but a bit warm fermented.

Can from old boss Phil. He brought back from a trip out west. (I gave him one of my home brewed porters that he loved.) Clear amber pour, nice frothy white head. The aroma is toffee, honey, and light fruit. Flavor is toffee, toast and a very sweet and malty lager but some crisp hops in the finish.
Can. Pours a dark copper color with white head. Citrus, orange, cereal aromas. Citrus, grainy, cereal, orange, bread flavors.

Appearance: pours with a large beige head that settles into a nice density, the beer is a slightly hazy average gold color 
Aroma: citrus, very faint
Taste: nice malt sweetness, caramel malt, some warmth to it, moderate bitter finish
Palate: average carbonation, light mouthfeel, bitter aftertaste
Overall: this would make a good session beer, easy drinking without any real strong flavors or aromas

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: APR 23, 2015 
Location: 12 oz bottle from Nikkis Liquors, 4/22/15


Aroma: The aroma is cereal and grainy malts with some light hop notes as well.

Appearance: A clear orange color with a fairly large off-white head and some mid-heavy lace.

Flavor: The flavor is light-medium sweet, clean flavor, with a light bitterness as well.

Palate: The body is fairly light, with a soft carbonation, and a clean, lightly dry finish.

Overall Impression: 
This one is decent overall, but not particularly interesting or exciting.  You could do worse.

12oz can from Corti Brothers, Sacramento. Pours light copper with a huge foamy off-white head and a toffee and citrus aroma. There is a tasty brown ale base with a hearty hop bitterness that sticks to the palate. Very easy to drink.

Amber with heavy red hue, white frothy head, and decent lacing. Biscuit, mild caramel, floral, and citrus. Medium bodied, silky, citrus, and mild lemon. Nicely balanced, medium bitter, lite dry note, and sessionable. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Can at home. Pours clear copper with a large, frothy off-white head, long retention with good lacing. Aroma is earthy and cereal malt, citrus, woody, and herbal hops. Flavor is crisp pale malt, medium earthy, woody, and spicy hops and medium bitterness with a dry finish. Medium body and moderate carbonation.

12oz can, unique artwork. Pours amber, thick white foam. Big dry hopped aroma. Smells of hops. Tastes like a very fresh, dry hopped Anchor Steam. Malty backbone, finishes with a light lingering bitterness. Very sessionable, I could drink this everyday. (4322)

Pours amber-orange from the can, billowy white head. Aroma is mostly bread, hint of citrus. Taste is caramel, bread, some ctirus hops. Characteristic chewy mouth feel. Its very close to Anchor Steam, but with sharper hops for a bitter finish. Nice, though I dont know why Id drink this instead of their classic Steam.

The malt tastes exactly like an anchor steam, perhaps a bit more potent. The hops have been cranked up quite a bit and are heavy on the citrus. This was a welcome addition to Steam, they should change their Anchor Steam to this formula.

Can from Corti Brothers. Pours copper with a near white head. Aroma of citrus and melon/tropical. Crazy fruits. Med + body. Flavor is some toasty malt, citrus note, and some crazy fruit. Pretty flavorful, and underneath all the flavor I can imagine the original Anchor Steam (my dads favorite back in his day). Kudos to the Anchor brewers for moving "Steam" along with modern hop. It finishes less than dry, pretty darn hoppy, and arguably bitter. Seems to leave some white grape behind each quaff. Now: next should be the Brotherhood DIPL. Cant wait.

12 ounce can from a 6 pack. The aroma on this is really nice with citrus, tropical hop notes. Lightly dank, light onion. Really nice. Beautiful transparent glistening orange body with a large, frothy, rocky off-yellow head present. Starts with a bitter, herbal hop flavor. Light grapefruit citrus notes, too. The middle has a little cereal malt sweetness, which balances well. Finishes with more of an herbal moderate hop bitterness. This is a really well-crafted beer. Damn, its good.

Pours a dirty gold; nearly clear. Modest head that leaves some streaky spots on the glass.

Plenty of West Coast hop aroma--grapefruit rind and a touch of pine. Light malt base to the nose.

Interesting complexity: This one starts off with a malt base that succumbs to the aforementioned hop bitterness. But I also detect a bit of fruity sweetness in the swallow, yet the aftertaste is bitter and long lasting. Leans to the full body side, good carbonation. Easy to drink.

Pours a finger and half of head on medium straw body.
The aroma is grain and caramel.
The taste is quite malty with a bitter finish.
The texture is smooth.
Enjoyable.
Pours a golden amber color with a white head. Citrus, hop, floral and malt aroma. Citrus, floral, caramel and malt flavors. Medium light body and carbonation. Floral and caramel finish.
Can. Semi-clear orange pour with a frothy white head. Cereal grains and mild grassy hops. Totally an outdoor summer beer.
Fruity aroma with a light amount of hops. Clear orange color with a medium white head. Bitter and sweet beginning with the sweetness lingering in the finish.
Kinda plain, I think the hoppiness has faded out of this one by now, but not a bad beer.

On draft at Tap 25. It pours a rich gold/copper penny color with an off white head. The aroma has some mild tea leaves, fruit candy and berries. The flavor is prickly with light caramel, tea leaves, hints of menthol, florals and fruit candy. Bready finish. Its decent, but Im not noticing any more hop aroma than the regular steam beer.

Pour out of 12 oz can, hazy orange pour with white head, aroma brought notes of biscuit, earth, grass, some herbal notes into some grain, slight yeast. Taste was grass, pear, touch of earth, slight grain and husky notes into some biscuit, toast, finishing sweet, dry.

A tough beer to rate. It would be a lot better if not dominated by a fruit yeastiness characteristic of all anchor beers. A rather tame beer as well for my taste, but this is supposed to be a drinkable somewhat quenching concert beer and for that it is kind of tasty.
12 ounce can. Orange copper color. Citrus throughout over a malty body with some caramel. Nose isnt there. Slight sweetness. Nice.

355ml can. Clear amber pour, nice frothy white head. The aroma is toffee, honey, and strawberry. Flavor is toffee, toast, metal, a very sweet and malty lager but some crisp hops in the finish. Really nice beer actually.
Didnt quite care for it. Has a bit of a funky aftertaste but I appreciate the effort.

From a can unto a Coos Light cold activated glass. Pours an amber brown with lots of frothy white head. Not much aroma. Mouthfeel is nice and thick. Taste is pretty blech. Like a generic amber ale with no flavor. Pretty bad.
Can from PUBR. Pours clear dark straw and highly effervescent with 1-finger off-white head. Nose is resiny hoppy, caramel malty. Tastes hoppy, caramel malty, crisp finish, more tart late.

Pint pour of moderate amber with full light off white head. Nose is biscuited malt and sharpness with mild hop notes. Flavor is malt forward, clean hop notes and biscuit. Fresh an clean, honestly, its pretty good.

Comes out of the tap a beautiful amber with a fairly thick white head. Aroma has firm malty and fruity notes. Flavor is mainly malty with a nice fruity underpinning. Mouthfeel has average thickness but good, strong fizz. Join this brotherhood!
Tap at 4th ave pub. Pours orange with small head. Nose is light hop and grain. Tastes of hop bitters, lemon, fiddele heads, grains, some other dried herbs. Crisp and smooth. A fine drinking common

2oz taster on tap, at HopCat Broad Ripple. Clear golden slight orange color. Thin off-white head, leaving good thicker sheets of lace. Medium body. Smooth, kind of crisp, lighter carbonation. Bread, hint of honey (?), biscuity malt, and a nice balanced amount of dry hop, works very well with the base. Moderate sweet, mild to moderate bitter. Tasty, easy-drinking balanced stuff.

The Sampler, Brooklyn tap: Pours amber with a whitish head. Aroma some hops, but nearly not as much as I expected when the citra banner was raised. Taste was slightly sweet. A little malty. Some earthiness. The hops didnt play nearly as much of a part as I though they would. Some tropical fruit flavors going down I suppose. Mint? I dont think so.

Draft at Stragelove. Slightly hazy pale orange copper pour that starts with an impressive large white frothy head. Scattered lace. Complex toasted malts. Feels nicely unfiltered. Buttered biscuits with a floral marmalade. Orange peels. Lemon thyme. Dandelions. Violet petals. Apricots. Bubble gum. Honey bamboo. Eccentric toasted wheat notes. Interesting enough though the body feels a tad more watery than juicy.
Tap at Lazy Dog. Pours a transparent amber with a thin layer of off white head. Taste and aroma of caramel, malts, and bitter citrus.

On tap at Joe Canals West Deptford.
Appearance: The body is clear with an amber hue, leaning slightly dark. The head is creamy and light tan.
Aroma: Fruity and malty. Big caramel and semi-sweet white wine with hints of cherry. Reminds me a little of a oaked chardonnay.
Taste: Mildly bitter with balanced flavors. Underlying caramel with white wine overlying, hints of grapefruit and cherry. Finish lingers a tad medicinal of cherry and caramel.
Palate: Full-bodied and crisp.
Overall: This is a great drinking beer. One I could put back a bunch of without thinking! What a nice beer.
